Comment: John, I commend you for taking the bus from Ewa to Downtown. That is laudable. The sad reality, is that our bus system has been at-capacity since the early 1980's.  It seems intuitive that since a single bus can fit 50-80 people, then if the City wants to decrease traffic congestion and improve mobility, why don't they simply add more buses?  The problem is that Honolulu's geography (narrow linear development between the ocean and mountains) squeezes Honolulu's traffic into a very limited number of major east-west thoroughfares.  This forces many bus routes to share the same roadways and results in a phenomenon called "bus bunching". 
Buses get caught up in clusters that crawl along at a snails pace, often with very crowded buses near the front and emptier buses in the rear.  For riders waiting at bus stops, instead of buses coming every 5-10 as scheduled, they get several buses all at once, and then long periods with no buses at all. I will explain more below.

President Kennedy's June 10, 1963 call for an end to the Cold War, five and one-half months before his assassination, anticipates Dr. King’s courage in his April 4, 1967, Riverside Church address calling for an end to the Vietnam War, exactly one year before his assassination.  Each of those transforming speeches was a prophetic statement provoking the reward a prophet traditionally receives.  John Kennedy's American University address was to his death in Dallas as Martin Luther King’s Riverside Church address was to his death in Memphis.” — James Douglass, “JFK and the Unspeakable:       Why he died and why it matters”       reviews at  www.jfkmoon.org/unspeakable.html

Comment: After the severe treatment of a cancer, the pain was excruciating and so I was prescribed oxycontin.  I took that for five years. At the same time I knew that I was a changed person; that really the oxycontin was upsetting my mind. So under the guidance of my doctor, I proceeded to get off of it. It took six months to get off from what many might consider a small dosage to start with. I went through all the withdrawal symptoms, shakes, tears, etc. and finally after six months my adult son said to me, "I now have my mother back."
Yes we do become dependent and going off of the drug is no picnic as the writer will find out if she chooses to get off of it. Those drugs do affect our brains, no doubt about it. I feel fine and am back participating in society as one senior should.

Comment: Under ObamaCare, we "insure" too much.  A $30 birth control prescription requires a doctor visit every six months ... unnecessary expense.  The doctor has to file a claim form, and has to employ a staff that has to sort through 10,000 different codes for every imaginable product or procedure, and for dozens of different insurance companies who all have their own codes.  His staff as to keep records and follow up on receipts of payment, and refile when they aren't paid.  The pharmacy has to do the same thing.  As do each of the insurance companies.  And it takes the same number of man-hours to process a $30 claim as a $30,000 claim, so this $30 claim adds about $300 of costs to the system.  That's why costs are rising.

A lot of people would lose their jobs if we went to a national HSA program, so we have to decide what we want: cheaper health care, or an inefficient jobs program?  You get a lot of propaganda opposing HSAs because they'll cost jobs and insurance company profits.

Comment: Ronald,

we don't actually have a front of the house. We are a chef 's counter, so we only employ BOH. We have a healthy 39.7% labor cost currently, which is above industry levels. My cooks all make a living wage, with the dishwasher being the lowest paid at $15/hr. A lot of people are misinformed about what is happening in our small restaurants.  Here's what a restaurant budget typically looks like: 100% = sales, 35% labor, 35% cost of goods sold, 10% rent, 10% utilities, fees, etc..., 10% profit. That "profit" is MY salary, and unfortunately it's more like 6%. We at Farm Spirit are looking to do about $220,000 in sales in the first year, which means I am going to be paying myself about $20,000 this year...which sucks, but oh well. I am paying my cooks double that. We are able to pay them more because I do not rely on the consumer to pay my employees with tips. This is not a scam. It's good business. It's ethical business. The average cook in this town makes $25K, which is despicable.

(a) Improper time or place; avoidance of examination or inspection; misrepresentation and concealment of facts

Comment: Prior to the advent of comments being posted on news articles, the public had very few avenues for stating its point of view on a matter written up. I remember in the day that letters to the editor - if you could get yours printed - was like winning the lottery considering the high wall of critique a editorial editor would put on those letters, especially those with a different point of view. So, in looking forward, today's forums allow for many more to provide their input into a subject. 

Now whether that opinion is good or not, I think any opinion put out on this is as valuable as the next opinion. Those who post way more than I should understand that. 

But one thing is for sure, don't let forums like this get so regulated so that a faceless, nameless newspaper bureaucrat determines what should be said in comments, and what should not. That will definitely happen should comments here degenerate into personal attacks and Il Duce-type posturing on issues.

Comment: If you extend your oil change intervals to 25,000 km and abuse your engine beyond belief by only driving short distances in cold weather you might shorten the engine life enough to have a detectable failure before the car dies of old age.  Otherwise, the rest of the car will die long before the engine.  Modern engines with modern oil are getting oil changes far too often.  If stretch one oil change, in this case by 10%, the odds of doing any detectable harm to the engine are zero.  If you only ever do every second recommended change, your engine will still outlast the car.  Oil changes are only for the benefit of the next owner in any event.  My truck has 410,000 hard km on it, and as you can probably guess - not maintained to any kind of a schedule, and still has never had to have a litre of oil added between changes.  Its now been overheated twice due to a radiator incident and still shows no signs of any damage or wear or drivability.

Comment: To put it mildly, Anchorage is not the prettiest of cities.  It's crammed with embarrassing architecture, miles of dirty and broken pavement, and frankly populated with a lot of mean and nasty people (**koff**comments here**koff**).  If it weren't for the Chugach Mountains looming right there, one could easily mistake Anchorage for any nondescript Soviet city in 1970s Siberia.  It's prettiest month is that one week at the end of September.  Frost that cake with six months of snow, and you've got a recipe for bland.  You'd be mistaken for thinking Christmas is colorful, what with all the *white* lights everywhere, and nary a twinkle in them.  And then there are the people who put colorful sweaters on trees in February, because... well... why not?  How silly!  How funny!  It's like rainbow sprinkles on an all-white cake.  Maybe I *can* make it through another day here.

Comment: I haven't read the entire essay, but the excerpts contained in this article don't indicate he was mocking the writers OR their work, simply making his stance on 'cultural appropriation' known. While he was clearly aiming for humour with concepts like awarding a gold medal for cultural appropriation, his core message of "explore other cultures, learn and assimilate knowledge" is hardly divisive or mocking. It used to be what we routinely prescribed to people as the solution for racism and other 'isms'. Pointing out that even native writers struggle to bridge historical divides to accurately capture native life in previous generations, given how different their modern life is? How is that controversial?

Punishing him for making those opinions known in his essay most definitely impacts his freedom of expression.  It blows my mind that people talk about intentionally de-platforming as if it's no big deal, as if private organizations cannot censor and only the government is capable of it.

Comment: This will create a schism in our society between those who have meaningful work and those who do not.  Those who work will resent those who are on the dole, and those who are receiving a government guaranteed income will be envious of those who work, and thus obtain a greater income.  Over time, those on the guaranteed scheme will press for continual increases in income and those working will resist them, leading to social confrontation.  I fail to see how this will lead to a better society.  I would rather that government regulate the introduction of new technology to ensure that our working-age population continues to have access to work that dignifies their existence.  What social benefits do we obtain by eliminating fast-food servers, cashiers, and clerks?  Products that are a few cents cheaper?  I do not think that our headlong and unthinking rush to AI and other digital innovations will truly benefit our society over the long run.

Comment: It seems counter-intuitive as well as not necessarily a good thing that as our general population ages our politicians are getting younger.

And many of us are also less sanguine than your editorial seems to be about the ability of the young millennial voters to discern whether politicians are really authentic and whether election claims and promises are valid, make sense, should work, are affordable and will deliver in the long term not just for today.

A case can be made that with age comes the wisdom of experience, historical knowledge, perspective and so a better chance to make valid comparisons and assessments.  As well, age tends to foster a cynicism about glitz, glibness and other superficialities disguised as substance.

One could argue that an in depth examination of the three main parties platforms and leaders in the 2015 federal election and the ultimate result bear out this caution regarding the benefits of an ever younger political class both as candidates and voters.

Comment: SD,  You may be interested in this: "Most discussion of government spending and deficits assumes that the federal budget consists of four principal parts: entitlements (meaning Social Security and Medicare); defense; non-defense discretionary spending; and interest. This perspective is misleading because it ignores the hidden welfare state (927 billion in annual spending in 2012): a massive complex of 79 federal means-tested anti-poverty programs.

The public is almost totally unaware of the size and scope of government spending on the poor. This is because Congress and the mainstream media always discuss welfare in a fragmented, piecemeal basis. Each of the 79 programs is debated in isolation as if it were the only program affecting the poor. This piecemeal approach to welfare spending perpetuates the myth that spending on the poor is meager and grows little, if at all."

Comment: The quote from the CDC is a little out of date, because assays developed over the last decade have shown that statistically more cases of Toxoplasma gondii are contracted from fecal oocysts now (in the USA) than from tissue cysts,  such as found in meat.  This is likely due to several factors, including excluding cats from meat production.  The oocysts are the more common source of infection, which can occur from drinking contaminated water, inhalation of contaminated playground dust, contaminated dirt under fingernails, children putting fingers in their mouth that has previously contacted contaminated soil or water, etc.  Remember, we are talking about infectious oocysts that you can't see with your naked eye, millions of them, shed from a single infected cat, lasting over a year in soil or water.  It takes only one oocyst to infect a pig under lab conditions, which is a model for humans.  Cat colonies and outdoor cats shed the most oocysts into the environment, versus indoor cats.

Comment: Ireland has had a long and at times very troubled relationship with England. The Irish see the Welsh and the Scots as cultural cousins. Ireland has bloomed since its entry to the EU (then EEC)  on Jan. 1st 1973. The Irish also understand British politics and see Brexit as  being caused by an internal spat in the Conservative Party. Before Brexit becomes effective the present PM, Theresa May must table all agreements related to EU exit in the House of Commons where they will be voted on. Brexit is far from a sure bet.
The Irish are also well ensconced on the Continent and are learning French, German, Italian themselves as well as making sure their children in Ireland are learning at least one foreign language. Ireland today has come a long way in terms of prosperity and insularity. The outbreak of renewed insularity in GB is seen as a belief that wrapping oneself in the Union Jack will ward off cold and hunger which to the Irish is laughable.
I am an Irish-German-Canadian.

Comment: Noble sentiment. But that kind of thing typically needs to be built into the project from the start. For example, MTRC put development rights up for bidding and do realty related activities as part of its integrated plan. Their rail revenues cover approximately 70-80% of O&M (hard to extract), while realty revenues make them profitable. But sadly, doesn't work well as an afterthought. Each station and vertical development rights have to be re-planned. And I also mean probably relocated. This TOD stuff is a joke in comparison. We have an elevated bus route, not a fully master planned system linking what we called 'social infrastructure' destinations. Hospitals, schools, shopping, government, visitor destinations, etc, need to be connected. That kind of planning takes a long time and optimizing technology for the destinations, not forcing us on one path. We didn't get close to doing it right in my eyes. No wonder developers are not interested.

Comment: Anyone who thinks that Grizzly Bears are a needed addition to our eco system is fooling themselves... We have Mountain Lions, Black Bears, Bobcats, Wolves and Coyotes creating enough danger as it is... Setting Grizzly Bears free to roam our forests will create more problems than they are worth... Ask yourself which animal would you least like to encounter on a nature hike... If you didn't say Grizzly Bear, you need to look up "Grizzly Bear" in the dictionary... You can't establish a community of killers in such close proximity of humans, and you can believe that there will be interaction between the two before you can change the month on your calendar... You can't release a cold blooded killer and expect it to not be drawn to the lowlands where Black Bears already live... They'll seek food relentlessly, and when they step out of the forest and into somebody's yard, you're going to be sorry that you wasted your government research grant on such a stupid and reckless idea!

Comment: Most contemporary scripts are garbage. They are so "of their time" that they are outdated and passe before the curtain goes up. Go to see a new play in Seattle and chances are you will see actors struggling with stilted dialogue and stereotypical, one-dimensional characters. 

Sure it is important to give contemporary playwrights a chance to shine. ACT is doing this with upcoming productions of "The Wolves," "Until the Flood," and "Oslo." But in dealing with new plays there's far too much chaff to wheat. It's great for companies to produce "world premiers" but it's equally important that they produce good relevant theatre. 

"The Crucible" is a very relevant play to produce in 2017. It speaks to the dangers of demagogues, theocracy, and mass hysteria. I'd say that's pretty apt for contemporary society.

Comment: This is fascinating.  The reporting as usual is poor. We do not know whether a plea bargain was offered, but it would have been atypical for the ADA to bring the case to trial before offering a plea deal (i.e. plead guilty in return for lowering charges).  If indeed a plea bargain was offered, the most likely reason the woman would have declined was the misguided belief that innocence guarantees acquittal.  Well, guess what, innocence does not guarantee acquittal.  Usually, juries will go with the prosecutor because the prosecutor represents "the people."  From the little bit that was reported on this case, it sounds like there was reasonable doubt.  Of course, we do not know what the "injuries" actually were.  A black and blue mark?  I suspect that they were in that category, but of course the details were not reported.  Kids do manage to get black and blue marks.  And swatting a kid on the butt does not warrant 7 1/2 years of prison.  Ah well, who cares.  The woman is not important.

Comment: Okay...so we as a species (and frankly all animals) evolve to operate with heuristics to organize the world around us. It helps us streamline our thinking so the dangers of the environment are easily identified, we know who to herd to, who to avoid, and also expend less energy. T

The 'binary' world is not an archaic system designed to keep people down as it is fairly consistent with sex identification we've always evolved to expect. Yes there are bona-fide trans-sexuals, fluid identifiers, who don't feel they fit structural gender norms. But the majority percentage identify as one or the other and it is just easier to operate day to day with binary pronouns and sex identity. Is it discrimination? I don't think so. Could we go further to accept people in the 'grey' area of gender identification? You bet! But stripping the majority of a very common identifier "man or woman" is making life more difficult for everyone.

Comment: Once the forest is dead--as in clear cut--it will never again exist, not on a human time scale anyhow. The big trees our white ancestors decided to clear cut took centuries to grow, and to reshape the land and hydrological cycle around them. 

What we have now is not a forest in any historical sense of the word; so "replanting" has more to do with recapitalizing logging and lumber mill investments than it does with restoring the real forest, and climate, our ancestors killed. 

There were societies in the Americas for as long as in Europe, some of them incredibly complex and populous. But industrialism never occurred to any indigenous American societies, and neither did clearcutting, the ecocidal murder of 20 Billion passenger pigeons and 50 million buffalo, or strip mining or nuclear weapons, or tar sand extraction.

Given that western-style industrialism is causing the worst extinction event in the geological record, I'm not sure that it can really be called "progress".

Comment: No where did the article state the majority deported were for Visa violations. The 77% figure provided would include corruption, Visa and other unspecified violations but no breakdown was given as to how many were for what.

Of the 462 deported in 2016 there were...

355 (77%) deported under the undefined "non-compliance" heading.
56 (11.7%) deported for "unspecified reasons".
50 (11%) deported for "criminality".
1 (0.3%) deported for "organized crime".

So you have 51 people deported for serious reasons and 411 people deported for questionable unknown reasons in 2016.

Comment: That's not exactly correct. Driving is a privilege, but voting is a legal right defined both at the national and state levels.

You do have to prove you meet the eligibility requirements to possess that right, but having done that, you can not be denied that right unless you forfeit it, such as by committing a felony. The privilege of driving, in contrast, you not only have to prove eligibility, but also competency (well, for certain, very lax definitions of competency), and are subject to ongoing regulation of your behavior while driving. If your driving privileges are revoked or suspended, you have more limited legal recourse for restoration than you do for your right to vote.

I think you are right to raise concerns about potential for conflating the two if people and even political leaders start to associate voting rights with driving privileges, but I don't think that inherently makes automatic registration a bad policy.

Comment: I presume that this commentary is not on the Web’s main page because of all the negative comments that would be posted. I wasn’t aware of it until I opened the print edition.  Council members Menor and Anderson have heard my testimony (over a year ago) on the means to complete the project (i.e., Plan A) by converting the steel wheels system to urban magnetic levitation (maglev). Mr. Menor heard it again when he was at one of the recent Senate hearings on SB 1183. Maglev would not only meet the terms of the FFGA but could do so while staying within the available funding through 2027 of $6.8 billion. They seem to be concerned about any changes causing delays and rising costs; where were they when the current project produced those results? A Supplemental EIS covering maglev could be completed quickly; its guideway would be less physically and visually imposing and the train would be quieter and better for the environment. Complete Plan A with maglev. No new taxes.

Comment: Pandora17; just a correction of your stated fact. Fr. Tony Flannery did not celebrate a public Mass, it was a private Mass; for a final celebration with people who were close to him. In Ireland that can amount to a large number of people and it did pan out that way, in a rural community hall, near his own family's homestead . The large turn out reflected the esteem & respect for the man. They had to erect an outdoor large tv screen for the many who could not be accommodated inside the hall. I can assure you that good sense prevailed & no follow-up action that we are aware of , followed. Had there been any, a strong counter reaction would have followed across the country. Discretion was certainly the better part of valour, for the Papal Nuncio & the hierarchy, with the awareness of their own failures in the past. I think they were very wise, given the history of Tony's situation. Had it been under BXVI's reign; I have no doubt but that the religious police would have been on duty, etc.

Comment: I see this assertion a lot, but have never read why some people believe it to be indisputable truth.  It is not.

"As humans, we also need rituals"

SOME people may DESIRE to particiopate in rituals, but to say that ALL people "need" rituals is not true.  

In the context of religion, some desire some rituals in certain contexts (they don't "need" ritual), others pretty much forgo ritual (for example, Quakers).  

In the early church, the eucharist was a meal, presided over by someone chosen from the congregation, or by the head of household, who might have been either a man or a woman. No priests.

The rituals that have developed during the history of the RCC and christianity in general,  were developed by men, and sometimes have become a bit ludicrous. When any small change from the GIRM becomes a matter for civil war in the RCC, the notion of  the importance of 'ritual" has gone too far, becoming an end in itself that is often even at odds with true prayer and true spirituality.

Comment: As a general principle, the fewer laws that violate any provision of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, the better. Alternative measures to achieve a society's goals must be found, unless doing so is impossible. And even if no other means are available, a law in violation of the Charter might still be found unconstitutional. 

This law violates provisions of the Charter with the intent to inflict an additional monetary punishment. In other words, the most lofty principles our nation adheres to are being violated in order to punish petty criminals further. Or, if one argues the intent is to help victims of crime, then Charter rights are being violated in order to compensate someone for their rights being violated. I would argue that's a human rights death spiral.

Comment: In 1900 Galveston, Texas, was destroyed by a hurricane.  This is still the worst natural disaster in the history of the USA: 6,000 to 12,000 people killed.  The island of Galveston was completely rebuilt - the ground, not the buildings - high enough to be safe from storm surges and flash flooding. 

A lesson learned?  Apparently not.  The USA has since built the fourth largest city in the country, in a known hurricane zone, in a swamp barely above sea level.  Proposed dikes have gone unbuilt.  All sympathy is due to the Houstonians, but the villain of the play is not the weather but a paralyzed political system.

Comment: The best part of the game was Tyler Bozak grinding.  Grind, grind , grind.  As I've always said, grinding is the most important thing, next to moving your feet. Comment: How about a public review and debate on tenured faculty's productivity?  As I recall, tenured faculty are only required to actually teach classes for about 1/3 of their time.  The other 2/3's of their time is split between research/writing and other academic related endeavors AND community involvement/contributions.  In some cases the research portion brings in revenue to the school system, and that is an offset to the time not spent in the classroom.

If this understanding is not accurate, publicize the actual arrangement for tenure.  Just don't load it up with with hyperbole and justification obfuscation...just the basic facts!

If during a period where the University if facing dire financial conditions and further eroding of state revenue support, do we have the luxury of faculty only being in the classroom for 1/3 of their time?  The basic mission of the a university is to teach the students...so let the faculty teach in the classroom unless their research is bringing in revenue!

"Sidewalk Maintenance and Liability in Ice/Snow" 

"Eugene City Code 7.375
Sidewalks, Curbs and Access Connections - Owner's Responsibility to Maintain: 
The owner of land abutting a sidewalk shall maintain the sidewalk and curb in good repair and safe condition. Access connection(s) shall be maintained in good repair and safe condition by the owner of land served by the access connection(s).  
 The city engineer may serve notice on the owner to reconstruct or repair the abutting or adjoining sidewalk, curb or access connection as conditions may require. A notice to reconstruct or repair and the owner's duty to repair shall be governed by sections 7.152 to 7.154 of this code."

Comment: The TDSB has a history of doing stupid things.

About 20 years ago it removed all the play equipment from school yards because it did not meet CSA (Canadian Standards Association) standards. 

It did so because of a perceived risk of harm to children despite no reports of injuries from equipment that had been in place for years. It did not have the money at the time to replace the equipment which I recall  eventually cost a $million (probably $5 million today).

This was a complete waste of money and play equipment. The situation arose because the CSA changed its standards, which they occasionally do. However, such changes were minor and intended typically only apply to new installations, not retroactively.

Is it not wonderful how fools can spend other peoples money so easily and without any accountability?

Comment: Banks in Alaska have been active in making HUD Title VI loans for 15 years. Comment: The author's grasp of the essence of this growing controversy is flawed. He asserts RussiaGate is more akin to Iran-Contra than Watergate and that "Both cases are, at their heart, about the scope of presidential authority". We already know RussiaGate is about much more and has much wider implication for America's democratic institutions. That the House, Senate, FBI and DOJ - whose leaders had sought so hard to protect Trump - should nevertheless find themselves investigating the possibility of collusion between administration officials and Russia to fix American elections far eclipses the importance of Iran-Contra - even the importance of Watergate. 

The author and the experts he cites are right to underscore the risks of granting immunity. Democrats, careerists in Justice and the FBI, and even Republicans whose personal integrity transcends party loyalty will want assurances that immunity is not a scheme hatched by Machiavellianists to shield those who might be guilty of high crimes.

Comment: Thanks for that detailed explanation (which I wasn't aware of) but I was referring to a defence lawyer trying to claim that an accused robber had consent to take someone's money or property. A defence lawyer isn't going to do his client any good by arguing that he had consent while holding a gun in someone's face.

But let's take the analogy closer to the case here. Say the robber knocks the lady down while snatching her purse, rendering her unconscious. When she comes to she's unable to recall anything about the incident. Does the robber get off by claiming he had consent to take her purse, a claim that she can't refute? Barring a case with no witnesses, no evidence of an assault and a victim with a history of losing consciousness, I would say not. Unfortunately, that's the situation in this case. There's no witnesses, no evidence of an assault, and the purported victim can't remember a thing.

Comment: An excellent article. 
To it I will add that the present call by some young African students is most likely an expression of their experiences of being culturally marginalised in higher educational institutions, their epistemic exclusion from scientific curriculae by virtue of language and cultural beliefs, and the past political and ongoing socio-economic practices that suppress(ed) their parents' aspirations. John Mbiti (1969) describes a concept of reality in traditional African thought as being rooted in the past and present, with very little weight being put on the 'non-real' space of the future. If we understand our students to be trapped in this inter-generational time-based reality, our task is to engage them educationally in ways that challenges this notion, by creating experiences wherein they see immediate benefits to science-based interventions within their own communities. Experience, not abstract discourse, is going to change the course of our society.

Comment: The headline here is a treat. Can you imagine what the mothers and fathers and daughters and sons and friends and neighbors of the soldiers killed and wounded "would think of it?" That war is unquestionably tied to us in modern-day Canada - through our economic expansion and  industrialization. It is not simply a waving of flag on Remembrance Day. Our rising in the world would not have occurred without those two world wars. We would be a nothing economically compared to what we are today. And our maple-leaf flag itself wouldn't exist if it not were for our soldiers, sailors and airmen during WWI. The maple leaf was the symbol and badge for Canadians in service - and not only soldiers at the battlefront. It came to symbolize the whole country. Should we only celebrate and honor things that make make us "feel good" and are deemed by the media as "politically correct?"

Comment: Is Alaska and are Alaska Natives better off as part of the United States?  If the answer to that question is yes, then a statue honoring the man who made it possible seems fitting. And while Natives undoubtedly suffered from racial discrimination over the years, and in some instances still do, they have also benefitted from laws that recognize their rights (ANCSA) and programs enacted to meet their needs -- Native hospitals and investments in village schools, water and sewer systems.   Bennie Benson, a Native, designed the state flag. It should also be noted that the Alaska purchase was a small part of Seward's career which is distinguished by his lifelong efforts to eradicate the oppression of blacks (slavery) and his major role in preserving the nation during the Civil War.  On balance, I think he deserves a statute. But if denied, the next time I visit Alaska I can travel to Seward on July 4.

Comment: There have been articles in ADN over the years on this; studs are a minority cause.  The principle reason for rutted roads stems from the aggregate (rock) size spec'd by DOT in the current asphalt mix.  In the 60's, 70's, etc a larger size was used and stood up to all traffic better.  It's more expensive so DOT now spec's a cheaper, smaller size that wears faster.  You never saw ruts like these in the 60's and 70's and studded tires were the norm then, not the exception.  Lane traffic density was the same; the Glen was a two lane highway then, everything drove them.  Late 70's, early 80's saw the first "All Season" tires show up, most were junk but BF Goodrich or GoodYear had one that was better than others, the Arriva or such was the type.

Comment: McKenna writes : “Among the anomalies: the CPI suggests meat prices have fallen 2.1 per cent from a year ago (April, 2016, to April, 2017. Dalhousie found an 11-per-cent increase in meat prices, just since January of this year.)” Of course, this kind of comparison over different time periods makes little sense. If you look at CPI meat prices over the same January 2017 to May 2017 span they rose 1.0%, still much less than the FPR estimate. For the other categories, based on the same time periods, these were the differences, with the NPR estimate following the CPI one: fish and seafood: 2.6%, -4.0%; dairy and eggs: -0.1%, -9.0%; bakery and cereal products: 0.5%, 0.5%; fruit and nuts: 2.2%, 9.0%; vegetables: 4.1%, 8.0%, other food: 0.7%, 3.2%; total food: 1.3%, 3.6%. (Weighting over the groups was based on 2015 basket shares at link month prices.) The difference between total food inflation rates when annualized (questionable since the data is raw) is 7.2 percentage points.

Comment: I am basing my remarks not just on studies but eight years experience dealing with their medical system. I posted a story that, in fact, did not rehash a piece of ideology--as your views do. Everyone is aware that UK survival rates need to be improved, though the evidence is unclear about the source of the problem + people disagree about the importance of survival rates as a metric. (The problem with it is that many people die of other causes before the die of cancer--this is more the case in the USA--so they are not listed as cancer fatalities). In any event, if the problem here was single-payer medicine, the problems in the UK would show up in other such European systems, which they don't. Your account of why drug costs are higher is false. Your remark on herceptin is also uninformed by not understanding the NIH approval system. Exxample: Kadcyla is not finally approved yet in the UK, but all that means is that the NHS is still negotiating its price. My wife got it two years there.

Comment: Chris

Site C is the third large dam on the Peace River. WAC Bennett was Site A, Peace Canyon was Site B. 

In addition there is Mica Dam, Revelstoke Dam, Kootenay Canal and Seven Mile Generating Station. 

There are also a number of other smaller dams that generate power that are not 'run of the river' style of generating stations on the Columbia/Kootenay river system as well as a few that I am aware of in the Lillooet region of the province. (Seton Lake and Carpenter Lake area)

There are even some large dams in the Kootenays on the Columbia/Kootenay that do not generate power that control water flow to support the other generating systems. 

Note that the largest, most damaging hydro electric facilities are on major rivers that are the furthest from the population centers in the lower mainland and southern Vancouver Island.  This is not coincidence I am sure. 

Example, why no hydro dams on the Fraser River?  Can't say 'salmon' because they destroyed the runs in other rivers.

Comment: The Lane County request by OpenTheBooks.com is for information that is... public, not private information. Lane County must provide responsive records without a $23,487 fee (like over 300 over governments in Oregon have already produced).

Comment: The storage of extra rims is a pain, but cheaper and quicker than switching tires on the same rims. 
I used to pull the studs every other year, when I had more time and energy, and have the studs replaced - as one or two seasons is about the best you can expect  from steel stud s- less recently with climate change impacts on winter roads- . and the fellow who used to re-stud my tires for me retired (not "re-tired"), :>)
I tried Blizzteks for two years and liked their performance, but they wore down as quickly as do steel studs, and are more expensive to replace.
Overall tho, I'd like to definitely add that driving more slowly in winter; staying aware of skidding tendencies of curves and on hills  - especially at lights or stop signs - , and keeping greater distances between you and other vehicles can help almost as much as studs... and please stay far more alert for pedestrians, critters and cyclists!!

Comment: Lots of folks like to complain that government is dysfunctional, as if dysfunction is some intrinsic property of the state. But government is often dysfunctional because it does precisely what we want it to do--and the things we want can't coexist. So, someday soon, someone will complain in these comments that RTD is a waste of money that can barely fill its trains. And people will buy that criticism because it jibes with what they see.  

Yet RTD was always going to be an unsatisfying compromise.  Voters wanted both a *regional* light rail system and the ability maintain local land use control. They got that, but they also got the consequences on display here: ~3,000 voters made the right call for themselves but reduced the effectiveness of a system designed for more than three million. There's nothing mysterious about RTD's dysfunction, then.  We've gotten what we wanted.  But turns out that what we wanted didn't make sense.

Comment: If you live in a dessert, or a water scarce area like the Karoo, tapping into groundwater is inevitable. We don't have a water problem per se, we have a water usage problem. 

The dangers of overtapping an aquifer, especially at the coast, are serious. You can also have the ground sinking in if an aquifer is tapped over much.

I think the City authorities are not applying themselves fully to the problem. Gene de Murro's idea of  a test is actually a very good one. People generally don't think about water, unless it's a problem. 

The City also want to develop the very area above the Cape flats aquifer. You can't have your cake and eat it. But they probably will, so generations down the line will have to deal with the problems.

Comment: The difference between a billion and a million:

This will give you a good sense of just how much a billion dollars is.  The difference is absolutely enormous.

Imagine you receive $1/second,( which works out an hourly rate of $3600/hour).  And imagine that you receive it every second of every day.  How long would it take you to become a millionaire?  
Roughly 12 days.

And how long would it take you to become a billionaire at that rate?  32 years!

That’s the difference between a million and a billion – 12 days vs 32 years.

Comment: It does not make sense. The private sector provides virtually all our needs and wants at a reasonable cost (because we can afford to buy them) but cannot provide health care at reasonable cost in comparison to single payer government run. There are at least three possibilities.

First, the private sector is providing more services, or higher cost services.
Second the single payer is providing less services.
Third a combination of the two. 

We certainly have examples of our Canadian system not providing some services which many people would expect. Being held in hallways. rather than emergency. Patients suitable for nursing homes being held in hospital beds. Waits for appointments

With single payer the patient has little or no choice.

With private sector the patient can choose the care desired. This should lower overall costs and provide the best service (the service the patient wants). 

The poor would have the Guaranteed Annual Income to cover all their costs, not just health care.

Comment: Good comment. I'm not happy with John Horgan's timid position on Site C - it is an indefensible disaster in waiting and he should say so.

One of the messages of the Joint Review Panel Report was that Hydro never seriously considered alternatives to Site C - particularly geothermal energy. Although, nobody has com up with a credible argument for why we need the power Site C is intended to provide, it has been shown (by CANGEA) that geothermal can achieve the same levels of baseload power generation - incrementally (as we need it) at a comparable cost and less environmental/cultural damage.

Comment: Reread the study...a VERY small and very biased sample (32,800 voters that was not representative) was used, found 339 self-identified non-citizens (about 1%) and 39 of the 339 said they voted (about 1/5 of 1%). The authors extrapolated that number to the entire country without considering the accuracy of their data - for example, they had information from 2008, 2010 and 2012, and 20 respondents changed their answers on the "citizenship question" for each survey. The original authors didn't even notice this.

The study used the data from the Cooperative Congressional Election Study, a non-partisan research group - they have criticized the methods used by the authors (including Richman - one 'h') and have demanded they withdraw the study...which doesn't matter because the authors can't get the study published in a peer-reviewed journal because of its amateurish methods...

So, you're gonna hang your hat on that? Read anything by Larry Sabato at U of Virginia that samples millions...

Comment: Like the others making comments I have enjoyed this series very much over the last 5 years. My current portfolio mirrors most closely that of John Heinzl. 

In the 1980s and 1990s my portfolio most closely resembled Chris Umiastowski's with one significant difference. My focus was not on technology companies, it was on western Canadian oil and gas start-ups. I did very well but about 25 years ago I started shifting my investment focus to the dividend payers. My new portfolio is also doing very well.

I mention this because I think an investor's focus or style must change over the investor's lifespan.  My equities investing life is now 45 years (I am 69). If I live as long as my parents did I could well have another 25 years of life that my equity investments must support. I can easily see switching my equity focus to ETFs picked by some robo-advisor.

Already I am losing interest in doing the research necessary for maintenance of my current portfolio

Comment: The stock market is a horse race where you are allowed to place your bets even when the race is half over. You are allowed to bet on the leaders. They can always stumble or be overtaken, but there is a large enough pack that a bit of prudent diversification has a high likelihood of success.
The individual investor does not have the problems of the fund manager, who must find a place for many millions in investment and is forced to put money on the laggards. ETFs are supposed to provide less risk, but they ensure that the profits of the horses in front are dragged down by the losses of many others coughing in their dust.

Comment: The issue now is whether Trump obstructed justice.  This is the relevant section of the US legal code: “(a) Whoever corruptly, or by threats or force, or by any threatening letter or communication, endeavors to influence, intimidate, or impede…. the due administration of justice, shall be punished as provided in subsection.”  Trump said he hoped Comey would end his investigation of Flynn.  There was no threat, no force, and no threatening letter or communication, so what is left?  It boils down to “corruptly,” defined in law as acting knowingly and dishonestly with the specific intent to subvert or undermine the integrity of something.  It will now be up to the Special Prosecutor to determine if Trump’s “hope” constitutes corrupt intent.  I do not believe so.  Case dismissed.

Comment: It's time to dismantle the incoherent bafflegab of posts like yours.    Canada's age class distribution of its spruce pine dominated boreal and sub boreal forests is getting older.  These post climatic climax forests are increasingly stagnant and characterized by decay processes.  Not only is the CO2 produced by standing decay not fully accounted for but these millions of hectares of stands are also producing increasing quantities of CO2 from respiration.

That's right, MACKINNONJWM, trees BREATHE just like all living organisms.  While Forests yield oxygen and consume atmospheric CO2 via photosynthesis, they also consume O2 for metabolic processes. It's called respiration and older, stagnant forests yield MORE CO2 from respiration than they produce O2 from photosynthesis.

canada's capacity to act as a carbon sink is great, but only if we recycle these aging, declining stands via harvest/reforestation or allowing them to burn naturally instead of suppressing fire as we do.

Comment: As a Lutheran Pastor, I concur in the editorial's position.  I am capable of getting myself into trouble from the pulpit without adding political endorsements as an issue.  As anyone who preaches knows, no matter how you try and frame the gospel issues you preach on, someone is likely to take offense at something that is the least bit controversial.  I have had some Mondays when my inbox is full, not only of the first person who had an issue, but who then managed to stir up some others who then weighed in.

As preachers, clergy are assumed to be subject matter experts in scripture and in doctrine.  But when we leave these fields of our "expertise" we leave ourselves open to the danger that our words  are no more than political statements, where we have no more credibility than other educated members of our society.  We need to think carefully about what we bring to the sanctity of the pulpit.  The Amendment is a reasonable limit on politics.

PR Chris

Comment: Most of the comments so far seem entirely to miss the major point of this piece, i.e., that if the basis step-up is repealed along with the estate tax, suddenly anyone who inherits anything (except possibly for cash), will pay income taxes when the inherited property is sold. That's massive new taxation on everyone that pays income taxes.

Compare this to the estate tax: a minuscule percentage of people are subject to it, and its effect can be mitigated to boot with financial planning.

Watch out for Trojan horses like these in the tax reform bill -- it will be full of them. The bill will offer a few crumbs to the middle class, sneak in other tax increases like these, and give a massive tax cut to the rich. That's all this has ever been about.

Comment: Many judicial decisions are based on subjective opinions, applied to diverse, protected class issues, in the context of the law. For example, deciding what constitutes an "undue burden" for an entire class of Alaskans. If one justice on the court is also a member of that class, he or she may more deeply, internally, and accurately understand what an undue burden truly is, how it feels, and how it impacts one's future. And could help inform the other justices. 
Diversity among decision-makers is critical and gaining acclaim because it discourages "groupthink," and brings improved decision-making. 
In Alaska, women comprise about 47% and men 52% of the population. Of the five AK Supreme Court justices, four are white men and the fifth, Dana Fabe, a woman, is retiring. It is up to Gov. Walker to choose one nominee. And that nominee will certainly be either a highly qualified white man or a highly qualified white woman. But only the white woman will give us a protected-class-diverse court.

Comment: Water from the town comes from two wells located in town and the Fort Casey well field, located out of town. Fort Casey is the primary source of water, the in town wells are used during the summer months when the demand is greatest.
http://www.townofcoupeville.org/department_files/water.htm

Remember that surface topography and distances may not be reflected in the underground aquifers. Contaminants can spread throughout an aquifer, given enough time. For example, salt water intrusion has been documented in some locations as much as 6 miles inland, so its reasonable that this is a concern on Whidbey where no where on the island is that far from salt water.

As for the Navy not testing your well, I suggest that you demand that Navy do so. I don't believe that OLF was used much for fire fighting training, which is the source of the chemical contamination, but Ault field had fire fighting training going on for years (decades).

Comment: It is a positive right, as part of social security systems.  Negative rights restrict what the state can do to you. Positive rights mandate what the state must do for you.  Attempts to ban abortion are about creating a positive right for the unborn, versus the mother's negative right to her own reproductive decisions.  Of course, a positive right to a monthly income for each child conveyed with parental pay or social insurance benefits (children of the disabled get an amount worth half their parent's entitlement) would greatly reduce the use of abortion services.  Of course, the Freedom Caucus types see this as promoting idleness (which is silly in a world of increasing automation).

Comment: "Terroristic threatening," in most states that have such a statute, doesn't refer primarily to political terrorism, although it can include it.  "Terroristic threatening" only requires a threat to commit violence, either to induce or dissuade another person to take some action, or simply to make the other person feel fear.  Sol Wachtler, a New York Appeals Court justice, was convicted of terroristic threatening for leaving messages on his estranged girlfriend's answering machine that appeared to threaten the woman's adolescent daughter if she did not return to her relationship with Wachtler.

Two of them — who worked in tandem — got treated to a fairy tale in installments, basically their stupid replies served as the basis for the next installment with "that special twist". And what was the tale about? Location changed between Trollhättan, Sweden and Switzerland. It was all about the two "clowns" having great difficulty finding their way around Zürich, looking for the  infamous "Gnomes of Zürich". ;)

Comment: The Legislature fiddles while the state burns.

A shutdown would not only cost the state millions of dollars in economic and investment damage, but even laying off every state worker would end up costing the state millions of dollars. Because state workers are laid-off, not furloughed like federal employees in shutdown, the state is legally required to cash-out the employee leave banks of every single employee effected. You can safely assume hundreds of thousands of hours of leave would have to be written off the books with checks, and long-service employees who have climbed the payscale will get large payouts (a quarter million or more for some folks I know who have several thousand hours in the bank).

The brinksmanship is a bad joke. It doesn't get anything accomplished other than making our state government look as dysfunctional as the federal government. The Legislature needs to do its damned job.

Comment: No need for a SO.  Get rid of the 2 pools and playoffs.  Invite the top 8 teams, go round robin, just as it used to be.  Whichever team's got the best record at the end of the tournament, that team wins.

If 2 teams are tied, then go with the head-to-head result.  If 3 teams, go head-to-head, then goal diff, and so on so forth.  I mean, there are other ways to run tournaments.

Doubt TSN would like that set-up, could affect their ratings.  Sudden death playoffs works much better for TV, build drama, 1-game showdown, gold medal final.  Great ratings.

I think it was TSN/Canada that pushed for the switch from the round robin to the current 2 pools, crossover playoffs building to the gold medal final.  Every 1ce in a while you get ties that hafta be decided by SO, can't have the games going 3 or 4 OTs.

Should the champ be determined by a SO?  Of course not.  But given the circumstances, had to be that way.

Comment: I'll address this one point of yours:

"The sky is falling?"

Yes, it is falling (metaphorically speaking of course).   It's falling very slowly though and it may not crush us to death but we will have to adjust - as a species of course.

I'm not talking about in our lifetimes and I'm not just talking about climate change.   I'm talking about other damage to the planet.   Coral reefs are suffering and there is over-fishing and there is significant plastic and other toxic pollution in the ocean and I really like seafood.

And coral reefs support 25% of ocean life.

But even if you're a vegan or a strictly beef-eater things might not be so great in the future either.   Grazing land is being destroyed and there are droughts and diseases.   

I do have hope though.  Maybe we can hold up the sky somehow with advancements or maybe we can adapt.   I won't be alive to see it and our children won't either.  Time moves slowly on a geological scale, grasshopper

Comment: A recession in in the government sector, precipitates a recession in the private sector. The private sector depends on government spending. When the capital budget is cut, thousands of people in the construction industry lose their jobs.  When education is cut, teachers lose their jobs. When state agencies cut, public employees lose their jobs. When revenue sharing is cut, municipal employees lose their jobs. 

When all these people lose their job, retail, food service, automobile dealerships, travel and  leisure, real estate, banking and finance--you name it--everybody is hurt. This is what happened in the 1980s.  We can't prevent painful cuts, but the legislature is making thing worse, by not acting now.

Comment: As someone who has been involved with the regulations on sulphur emissions from ships since 2004 I have to say the author has rather missed the boat (insert bad pun groan here).

Exhaust gas cleaning systems can be installed on ships to eliminate the sulphur and dramatically reduce the particulate matter allowing the ships to use cost effective heavy fuel oil (HFO) 

The alternative is to refine the HFO into diesel fuel. This. however, creates additional CO2 emissions, has a significant cost impact, and does little to reduce the most harmful sub 5 micron particulate emissions. 

The technology is relatively new and is installed on only small part of the commercial fleet. As it matures, additional PM, NOx and CO2 reductions will be possible. 

As for the 1000's of cars emissions comparison - this is a misleading statement at best.  How many pickup trucks would it take to deliver grain from Thunder Bay to the global markets? Several thousand. I have a much better idea, use a ship.

Comment: I understand that this is an AK newspaper, but the writer is showing an ignorance regarding Natives issues.  The author seems to take umbrage over AK having 40% of the total number of recognized tribes but no representation.  While I agree that AK Natives should be represented, that 40% is misleading.  When the government officially recognized AK Native tribes, they seemed to codify almost every separate native village as a separate tribe, which is radically different than how it was done with the Native American tribes where typically all the villages in an area with the same culture were grouped into a tribe.  That means that while there are fewer Lower 48 tribes, they are much larger.  Estimates place the total number of AK Natives living in AK right now as between 110,000-125,000.  If we were to consolidate those all into one tribe, it still wouldn't even break into the Top 5 of the largest federally-recognized tribes, and represents only about 2% of the total US Native population.

Comment: Ellis Island/Immigration laws.
-
* The first federal immigration law is passed in 1790-
* 1875- prostitutes, criminals & lunatics denied US entry. 
* 1903-Anarchists are denied admittance 
* 1907-denied entry to physical and mental disabilities & children arriving without adults.
* Immigrants are Jews,Poles, Hungarians, Czechs, Serbs, Slovaks and Greeks, Syria, Turkey & Armenia
http://www.history.com/topics/ellis-island
-
Arrival at the Island and Initial Inspection-The two agencies responsible for processing immigrants at Ellis Island were the United States Public Health Service & the Bureau of Immigration (later known as the Immigration and Naturalization Service-INS)

The two main reasons why an immigrant would be excluded were if a doctor diagnosed that the immigrant had a contagious disease that would endanger the public health or if a legal inspector thought the immigrant was likely to become a public charge or an illegal contract laborer.
https://www.libertyellisfoundation.org

Comment: Sorry, I wasn't clear. The cost of the rebuild of 29th and Willamette 5 years ago was $800.000. As you may know, to rebuild a road you need a preliminary analysis  in order to make a plan to do the work. The work plan involves engineers, often EPA analysis, sometimes historical analysis, location of above ground and underground utilities, project management so the job is done in the right order, meetings with contractors to lay concrete, move utilities, coordination with bus services and emergency services. Also, collaboration with adjacent property owners, sometimes procurement of right of way (land), negotiation for price, waivers, permissions. Then there is the cost of removing concrete, laying rebar to stabilize concrete, traffic diversion plans to move cars while the work is being done, laying of concrete, reshuffling traffic as new concrete is laid, removing and adding stripes, crosswalks,  traffic lights, timing. And if the work is done at night, add additional labor.

Comment: Tita Girl:

Like Trump, you’re making a deceptive claim by citing premium increases (due to a significant degree to the instability that Trump has introduced into the system) and ignoring the financial assistance that offsets much of the premium cost. In Arizona, 80% of people receive financial assistance to help them pay their premiums. In 2016, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation, the monthly Silver Premiums after financial assistance for a 40-year old non-smoker making $30,000/year in Arizona was $207/month. In 2017, it was $207/month. That’s an increase of 0%.

Today Trump tweeted that premiums went up 204% in Alaska. That's a very deceptive half-truth. First, that’s an increase over a 4-year period, not a one-year increase, and, second, it doesn’t factor in the financial assistance received by 93% of Alaskans. They are, in fact, paying less than they did in 2013 (if they could even get insurance before the existence of the ACA exchange).

Comment: Actually the way it would work is we would be on the same clock as the West Coast in the winter and they would jump an hour ahead of us when they go to Daylight Savings Time in the summer.

Basically, central AK would stay 2 hours ahead of solar time year-round (as we are now most of the year with DST). That puts more of the available daylight in the evening - particularly in winter.
Southeast AK will go back to the PST zone as they were before the Sheffield time zone merger in 198?
I don't see why western Alaska has to follow suit but in the end the numbers on the clock are relative. One nice result is we simply don't have to change our clocks this fall or ever again.

Just keep in mind that solar noon is at 2PM.

Comment: The unemployment rate does not measure how many people should fall into the unemployed category and exaggerates employment and how much of the potentially working population is employed. However, the labor force participation exaggerates the number of people who are out of the labor force because it picks up people who are retiring for example. The best rate to make up for these factors is the US U-6 rate-- often called the "Real Unemployment Rate" which adds to "unemployed" the people who have a sought a job but cannot get a job "discouraged workers", plus it picks up part time workers who have to work for economic reasons (they are counted as unemployed because they cannot find full time employment). Using this measure, unemployment in Colorado rises from 2.3% to 69%, and Hawaii unemployment rises from 2.7% to 7.1%. Hawaii falls from 3d to 10th in rate of employment.

Comment: By strictly constitutional means of course, the Electoral College ought to be abolished. Just as (17th Amendment) the people of each state now directly elect their Senators, rather than the original plan that was in place for more than a century, that State Legislaatures elected Senators. Abolishing the anachronistic Electoral College would not destroy our Republic, any more than the 17th Amendment. Special interests, in both cases, are the only voices that plead for an archaic system.

There are special interests, that is to say, that are fine with the popular vote loser being the Electoral College winner - as most recently in 2000 and 2016. Where a minority chooses the head of state with political power, that is aristocracy rather than democracy (popular rule) - which is sure to leave the majority discontented. Let the people assert their unquestioned right to be ruled only with "the consent of the governed" (Declaration of Independence.)

Comment: I feel many coaches make the game too hard. I realize the size and speed of defenses really affect the offensive game plan. Coaches and players spend hours watching film and looking for cracks where 1/10th of a second makes the difference. Ever since I was a little kid the game always comes down to who blocks and tackles the best. Who can cause turnovers. Who can keep away from stupid penalties and mistakes. It's really pretty basic. Only the strong survive, not only physically but mentally.  I think coaches need to back off and let the players play. Let the QB call the majority of plays. Let the defensive linebackers call the formations. Let the coaches run players in and out keeping them fresh. Once you can establish field position, then open things up and strike when odds are in your favor. Teams need more discipline including the coaches. That's why the Patriots are favored.Denver can beat these guys if they play together and keep focus. This team isn't used to having butts kicked.

Comment: The contingency cost is based on the size of the construction cost and not the other way around. Contingency cost is basically revenues minus the cost of construction. It's what's left over after you've paid for rail. 

It shouldn't be part of the rail cost. What it really is, is insurance that the construction cost will be covered. Currently contingency is about 1.2 billion. We have used so little of it so far that it seems like we won't need three billion to cover total financing costs? The feds are way over the top.

The tendency for rail opponents is to include contingency cost with construction cost. That's totally illogical. Nor is it even "consistent". And what's the point? There isn't much substance in this discussion. We're only talking about concerns of the federal bean counters.

If the city and county agree to swap, the swap is going to happen.

Whether the city or county can then build is all just about money.

Comment: We shouldn't have a corporate tax at all.  It's double-taxation, because we also tax dividends and capital gains.

Corporations don't pay taxes.  Their customers do.  It's a cost of doing business that's added onto price in order to net an after-tax profit that's sufficient to attract investment capital, relative to risk.  When you over-tax and over-regulate corporations, YOU pay for it in the price of everything you buy.

Example of how that 21.2% was derived.  XYZ Inc makes $10 million of profit this year, on which it's tax would normally be $3.5 million.  But it lost #3,943,000 last year, which is carried forward as a tax deduction from this year's earnings, making the net taxable income $6,057,000, and the net tax $2.22 million on this year's profits, but 35% of the net profits earned over both years.

All this to say, the whole system is as sick, if not sicker, than the sickest patient.
Top-heavy administration is putting everyone's health, and life, in some cases, at risk.

Comment: Learning left foot braking is a useful skill to have especially when highly precise low speed manoeuvring is required such as hooking up a trailer or in conditions of low traction or easing into tight spots. Using the brake to control the speed of the vehicle is more precise than using the accelerator and in conditions of low traction will help both drive wheels to turn rather than spinning one. This technique is called Controlled Throttle Management(CTM) and this is how it is done. Press hard on the brake pedal and shift into the appropriate gear. Gradually increase the throttle till the car is trying to move. Now with light removal and application of the brake, the car can be moved in tight increments with precise control of speed and position. Very little movement of the brake pedal is required and the throttle needs to be held at a constant engine speed - usually about 1000 rpm. When connecting trailers I even shift my truck into 4 low for even more precise control.

Comment: The mere smell of alcohol does not give a cop justification to search a vehicle - because he doesn't yet have any reasonable suspicion that a crime has been committed. If the driver fails a field sobriety test, then the cop might have cause/reason to arrest the driver, impound and search the vehicle, etc. But the smell of alcohol coming from a drunk passenger certainly wouldn't justify a full-blown search of the car.

Similarly, the mere fact that a dog alerted on the smell of "marijuana or another drug", without distinguishing between the two, does not give a cop justification to search. The dog might well be alerting because there's an "open container" of marijuana in the trunk or cargo area - which is not a crime under CO law.

Comment: Yes, you are right- you can fly with lithium batteries.  Here are the rules:  https://www.faa.gov/about/initiatives/hazmat_safety/.   Basically, e-cigarettes, or "spare" lithium batteries are only allowed as hand-carries, but not in checked baggage. Other devices which already have the lithium batteries installed in them are allowed in checked baggage - certainly legal, but not a good idea at all, in my opinion, given the proliferation of cheap lithium batteries of questionable quality and stability from China which are floating around out there.

The gentleman in the article didn't break any rules by having the e-cigarettes in his hand-carry.  My original point was that it's a reality check - a good reminder when flying to make sure these things are in one's carry-on, and NOT in any checked bags. I wonder how many people forget or don't really even think about it because they don't think it matters - a quick youtube search for "lithium battery fires on airplanes" shows otherwise.

Comment: Hi Amy,
I can understand why it sounds like this is what I was looking for - that was not my intention.  Let me be more clear! The reason I felt compelled to write about this is to fight the stigma of mental health care. While I greatly appreciate the confidential nature, it hurts us all to have mental health in this separate "unmentionable" category. When I look at much of what is going on in the world, I see underlying roots in mental health issues. I am often inundated by requests for referrals to good family therapists, child therapists, medication providers etc. Why not let the huge number of people in Anchorage who are using these providers and clinics give a consumer's opinion of their efficacy while also taking the category of mental health out of the shadows?
